issue.title: Implement important series-to-series transformers

labels.name: implementing framework
labels.description: Implementing frameworks for new learning tasks

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
Some series-to-series transformers that would be useful.

### unfitted, single-series, simple

- [ ]  **binning/aggregation transformer**

Behaviour:
returns the sequence of [aggregator application] (e.g., count) in the bins. Index is start time, end time, or index (from start) of bin, depending on index hyper-parameter

Hyper-parameters: 
bin specs - start: time/index, end  : time/index, numbins : integer
index - 'start', 'end', or 'bin'
aggregator - function to apply to values within bin, default = count

alternative to bin specs: index sequence

- [ ] **truncation transformer**

Behaviour:
cuts off any entry in the sequence with index outside [lower, upper]

Hyper-parameters:
 lower, upper : time

- [ ] **simple equal spacing transformer**

Behaviour:
intra/extrapolates series to the nodes by the specified strategy, e.g., fill in nearest or next (careful with boundaries)

Hyper-parameters: 
node specs - start: time/index, end  : time/index, numsteps : integer
index - 'start', 'end', or 'bin'
strategy - 'nearest', 'last' , 'next', 'pw_linear'

alternative to node specs: index sequence

- [ ] **re-indexing transformer**

Behaviour:
changes the index by a the strategy indicated in the reindexing parameter
integer = replace with ascending count
field = get from data frame column

Hyper-parameters: 
strategy - 'integer', 'field'

- [ ] **index extractor transformer**

Behaviour:
creates a series from the index of the series

- [ ] **NA remover transformer**

Behaviour:
removes sequence elements that are numpy.nan

- [ ] **padding transformer**

Behaviour:
pads a sequence/series with value at start or end until it has the desired length

Hyper-parameters: 
where - 'start', 'end'
what - value
length - integer
optional: index treatment


- [ ] **NA imputer**

Behaviour:
Fills in NA values by the specified strategy

Hyper-parameters:
strategy - 'nearest', 'last' , 'next', 'pw_linear'


### unfitted, single-series, reduction

- [ ] **interpolation transformer**

Behaviour:
uses a scikit-learn regressor or classifier to interpolate to the specified index set.
Fits series values against series index, and uses  the regressor/classifier to predict value from index

Hyper-parameters:
index set
estimator - sklearn regressor

- [ ] **Supervised NA imputer**

Behaviour:
Fills in NA values by the specified strategy by using a scikit-learn regressor or classifier. Fits non-NA series values against series index, and uses the regressor/classifier to predict value from index

Hyper-parameters:
strategy - 'nearest', 'last' , 'next', 'pw_linear'

- [ ] advanced: exogeneous or multi-column versions


### unfitted, multiple-series

Note: the below are "unfitted" since they run on the entire series

- [ ] **index homogenization transformer**
Behaviour:
Looks up the indices for all the series and introduces them for all the series. Fills in values at new nodes by the specified strategy.

Hyper-parameters:
strategy - ' NA', 'nearest', 'last', 'next'


### design questions

* would it make sense to create an "interpolator" class which in predict takes a series and an index sequence and returns the values?
* does it make sense to expose dedicated index parameter interfaces in some of the above?

body:
Probably easy since simply might be able to re-use xpandas transformer interface.
But this needs to be checked.
Also consider to migrate interface or have an sktime native interface for reasons of package stability and compatibility.

issue.title: TSC/TSR: implement pipeline building functionality with transformers on y

labels.name: implementing framework
labels.description: Implementing frameworks for new learning tasks

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
xpandas provides functionality for fusing series-to-tabular transformers with tabular supervised learning methods.

This should be interfaced, or replicated in the more general interface.

In this interface, it should be possible to chain series-to-series transformers (e.g., truncation) with series-to-tabular transformers to obtain a series-to-tabular transformer, or series-to-series with series-to-tabular with a tabular SL method to obtain a TSC/TSR method.

Conditional on a consolidated interface design as in https://github.com/kiraly-group/sktime/issues/5 and https://github.com/kiraly-group/sktime/issues/6.

If easy interfacing is not possible, it may also require separate pipeline design, in this case please raise issue of pipeline API design.

body:
Part 1. General design.

Summary:
For the moment, there is only a low-level interface, as long as the estimator high-level/task compatible interface is not consolidated.
The transformer design is a direct generalization of sklearn's transformers and pipelines, with pipelines being a first-order composition operation of type transformer x sup_learner -> sup_learner.

A slight generalization included is the "pairwise transformer" which is a transformer of 2nd degree, abstracting from sklearn's distances/kernels found in metrics.pairwise.
This is to resolve the ugly interface bloat when an abstract metric is plugged into an kernel or distance based algorithm such as k-nn, and to preserve conformity with the pipeline and hyper-parameter formalism.

Please feel free to comment/criticize. Further parts with specs follow below.

Part 2. Transformer. 

should be a class with parameters, attributes, methods.
Does not use abstract base class. Inherit from sklearn.BaseEstimator?

Parameters - private variables. Correspond to "hyper-parameters" to be set or tuned. Like in supervised estimator. Important parameter that a transformer may like to have: target name (column of X, below, to be considered as the sklearn y)
Attributes - private variables. Correspond to "model parameters" set by the fit method. Not to be set by the user or via an interface.

Constructor _ _ init _ _
arguments: all parameters, explicitly, with sensible default setting.
behavior: Sets self.parameters to the values provided.

public method fit
arguments:
X - an xpandas data frame which contains only primitive types or series of primitive types; or, a pandas data frame. no default.
optimal argument:
sample_weight - a vector of weights, equal length to X.
behavior:
fits model and stores it in attribute variables. May access but not modify parameters.
note: there should be no optional y, unlike in the sklearn design. I think the composition interface needs to take care of this, rather than the transformer itself.

public method transform
arguments:
X - an xpandas data frame which contains only primitive types or series of primitive types; or, a pandas data frame. no default. Column headers and types should be the same as of fit's X argument
optimal argument:
sample_weight - a vector of weights, equal length to X.
behavior:
Returns an xpandas, or pandas, equal length to X, with transformed columns having headers defined by the transformer. May access attributes and hyper-parameters. May not modify attributes and hyper-parameters.

optional public method inverse_transform
arguments:
X - an xpandas data frame which contains only primitive types or series of primitive types; or, a pandas data frame. no default. Column headers and types should be the same as of fit's X argument
optimal argument:
sample_weight - a vector of weights, equal length to X.
invert_vars - a list of variables to recover, subset of variables of the X passed to fit
behavior:
Returns an xpandas, or pandas, equal length to X, with back-transformed columns, named as passed to transform within its X. Only the columns in invert_vars are recovered, if that parameter is passed. May access attributes and hyper-parameters. May not modify attributes and hyper-parameters.

public method get_params
arguments:
deep - a boolean indicating whether parameters of nested estimators should be returned
behaviour:
returns string -> value dictionary of parameters, following the sklearn naming convention (nested estimators' parameters by < estimatorname >__< parametername >, returned if and only if deep = true)

public method set_params
arguments:
string -> value dictionary of parameters, following the sklearn naming convention (nested estimators' parameters by < estimatorname >__< parametername >)
behaviour:
sets parameters, and nested parameters if provided, to the values as defined by the dictionary mapping

Part 3. Pairwise transformer aka degree 2 transformer.

should be a class with parameters, attributes, methods.
Does not use abstract base class. Inherit from sklearn.BaseEstimator, or transformer?

Parameters - private variables. Correspond to "hyper-parameters" to be set or tuned. Like in supervised estimator.
Attributes - private variables. Correspond to "model parameters" set by the fit method. Not to be set by the user or via an interface.

Constructor _ _ init _ _
arguments: all parameters, explicitly, with sensible default setting.
behavior: Sets self.parameters to the values provided.

public method fit
arguments:
X - an xpandas data frame which contains only primitive types or series of primitive types; or, a pandas data frame. no default.
optimal argument:
sample_weight - a vector of weights, equal length to X.
behavior:
fits model and stores it in attribute variables. May access but not modify parameters.

public method transform
arguments:
X - an xpandas data frame which contains only primitive types or series of primitive types; or, a pandas data frame. no default. Column headers and types should be the same as of fit's X argument
Xnew - an xpandas data frame which contains only primitive types or series of primitive types; or, a pandas data frame. no default. Column headers and types should be the same as of fit's X argument
optimal argument:
sample_weight - a vector of weights, equal length to X.
behavior:
Returns an named 3D array K. First dimension is indexed by rows of X. Second dimension is indexed by rows of Xnew. Third dimension is indexed, with transformed columns having headers defined by the transformer. (footnote: we probably should use xarray for this if there is more than one index in the 3rd dimension, otherwise just the vanilla array. Generally/formally, it should be a xpandas/xarray cross-over but that would be unnecessary overkill)
May access attributes and hyper-parameters. May not modify attributes and hyper-parameters.

public method get_params
arguments:
deep - a boolean indicating whether parameters of nested estimators should be returned
behaviour:
returns string -> value dictionary of parameters, following the sklearn naming convention (nested estimators' parameters by < estimatorname >__< parametername >, returned if and only if deep = true)

public method set_params
arguments:
string -> value dictionary of parameters, following the sklearn naming convention (nested estimators' parameters by < estimatorname >__< parametername >)
behaviour:
sets parameters, and nested parameters if provided, to the values as defined by the dictionary mapping

Intermezzo: common examples for degree 2 transformer.

A. low-rank kernel/distance by inducing points.

Fit = learning the inducing points Z, based on training data Xtrain
Transform = computing kernel matrix between X and Xnew, using inducing points Z

B. median distance bandwith heuristic for Gaussian kernel

Fit = compute median distance between (uniform subsample of) training data point pairs, store this as fitted parameter
Transform = compute Gaussian kernel matrix between X and Xnew, using that median distance

C. pruned/tuned dynamic time warping

Fit = compute pruning/tuning parameter for DTW, using heuristic, or GridSearch on an approximation criterion
Transform = compute DTW distance matrix between X and Xnew

Part 4: pipelines

a class with attributes and methods.
Does not use abstract base class. Inherit from sklearn.BaseEstimator, or transformer?

Constructor _ _ init _ _
arguments: list of triples or pairs. If triples, should be (estimator name, estimator, variable names). If pairs, should be (estimator name, estimator)
behavior: constructs transformer or supervised learner like object, obtained from composing the estimators in the sequence, applying to the respective variable names (if specified), or all variables (if not specified)

"final type" = type of estimator obtained from composing. Can be transformer, or supervised learner.

Always has "fit" method - same as in sup.learner/transformer, depending on final type

Has "transform" method iff final type is transformer. As in transformer.

Has "inverse_transform" method iff final type is transformer and all component atoms implement it. As in transformer.

Has "predict" method iff final type is supervised. As in supervised learner.

public method get_params
behaviour:
returns string -> value dictionary of parameters, following the sklearn naming convention (nested estimators' parameters by < estimatorname >__< parametername >)

public method set_params
arguments:
string -> value dictionary of parameters, following the sklearn naming convention (nested estimators' parameters by < estimatorname >__< parametername >)
behaviour:
sets parameters, and nested parameters if provided, to the values as defined by the dictionary mapping

note: caching/memory functionality as in sklearn is nice to have eventually, but not a priority at the moment

Part 4-prime: 
composites with degree transformer

There are two options to implement this via pipeline:
(a) estimator, e.g., 1-nn fit/predict method recognizes input format (xpandas 2D, or 3D array?), pipeline just passes deg.2 transformer's output on. Problem: handling of storing training set unclear - e.g., for "compute dist(Xtrain,Xtest)"
(b) there is a "degree 2 supervised learner" too - X-inputs to fit/predict are relevant parts of the distance matrices. deg.2 transformers need to be composed with deg.2 supervised learners

Ideas/suggestions?

Part 5 - single row transformer and wrapper

note: this is inspired by Ahmed's "single series transformer" and sklearn's FunctionTransformer

should be a class with parameters, attributes, methods.
Does not use abstract base class. Inherit from sklearn.BaseEstimator?

Parameters - private variables. Correspond to "hyper-parameters" to be set or tuned. Like in supervised estimator.
Attributes - private variables. Correspond to "model parameters" set by the fit method. Not to be set by the user or via an interface.

Constructor _ _ init _ _
arguments: all parameters, explicitly, with sensible default setting.
behavior: Sets self.parameters to the values provided.
public method transform
arguments:
X - a single object, or an xpandas row. no default. 
behavior:
Returns a single object, or an xpandas row
May access attributes and hyper-parameters. May not modify attributes and hyper-parameters.

public method get_params
behaviour:
returns string -> value dictionary of parameters, following the sklearn naming convention 

public method set_params
arguments:
string -> value dictionary of parameters, following the sklearn naming convention (nested estimators' parameters by < estimatorname >__< parametername >)
behaviour:
sets parameters to the values as defined by the dictionary mapping

optional (most single row transformers will not have this):
public method fit
arguments:
X - an xpandas data frame which contains only primitive types or series of primitive types; or, a pandas data frame. no default.
optimal argument:
sample_weight - a vector of weights, equal length to X.
behavior:
fits model and stores it in attribute variables. May access but not modify parameters.

Part 5 continued:

RowApplyTrafo or similar, sub-classes transformer

has parameters:
singlerowtrafo - single row transformer
optional parameters:
variables - which variables to apply to (in sequence), if row transformer is multivariate

get_params, set_params access singlerowtrafo's parameters via the usual syntax (i.e., "deep" parameters)

fit does nothing if singlerowtrafo doesn't have one
fit calls singlerowtrafo's fit (on variables) if it does

transform(X) applies singlerowtrafo to all rows of X and returns the so-transformed xpandas frame
Add `check_input` argument to init with default set to True, to sidestep input checks in ensembles and pipelines.
